ABSTRACT: The program calls a method that parses doubles and can cause the thread to hang.
OWASP: A9 Using Components with Known Vulnerabilities

ABSTRACT: Untrusted data is passed to the application and used as a regular expression.  This can cause the thread to over-consume CPU resources.
Interpreting user-controlled instructions at run-time can allow attackers to execute malicious code.
Allowing unvalidated user-input to influence the run-time environment of dynamically executed code can allow attackers to execute malicious code.
Interpreting user-controlled instructions at run-time can allow attackers to execute malicious code.
Deserializing user-controlled object streams at runtime can allow attackers to execute arbitrary code on the server, abuse application logic or lead to denial of service.

TITULO: Dynamic Code Evaluation: Unsafe XStream Deserialization
ABSTRACT: Deserializing user-controlled XML documents at run-time can allow attackers to execute malicious arbitrary code on the server.
Deserializing user-controlled XML documents at run-time can allow attackers to execute malicious arbitrary code on the server.
Allowing user input to directly alter file permissions may enable an attacker to access otherwise protected system resources.

Concatenating unvalidated input into a URL can allow an attacker to override the value of a request parameter.  Attacker may be able to override existing parameter values, inject a new parameter or exploit variables out of a direct reach.
The program allows an attacker to control core components of the Hadoop cluster on which the client application runs.
The Job submitted to a Hadoop cluster can be tampered in a hostile environment.
Including unvalidated data in an HTTP response header can enable cache-poisoning, cross-site scripting, cross-user defacement, page hijacking, cookie manipulation or open redirect.

Including unvalidated data in Cookies can lead to HTTP Response header manipulation and enable cache-poisoning, cross-site scripting, cross-user defacement, page hijacking, cookie manipulation or open redirect.

Including unvalidated data in an SMTP header can enable attackers to add arbitrary headers, such as CC or BCC that can be used to leak the mail contents to themselves or use the mail server as a spam bot.
Usage of user-controlled or untrusted data to define HTML sanitizer policy could allow an attacker to circumvent the sanitization requirements and launch cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.
Allowing user input to control Intent parameters could enable an attacker to control the behavior of the subsequent activity.
The method writes unvalidated input into JSON. This call could allow an attacker to inject arbitrary elements or attributes into the JSON entity.
Constructing a dynamic LDAP filter with user input could allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning.
Executing an LDAP statement that contains a user-controlled value outside the filter string can allow an attacker to alter the statement's meaning or execute arbitrary LDAP commands.
Writing unvalidated user input to log files can allow an attacker to forge log entries or inject malicious content into the logs.
Writing unvalidated user input to log files can allow an attacker to forge log entries or inject malicious content into the logs.
Executing IMAP commands coming from an untrusted source can cause the IMAP server to execute malicious commands on behalf of an attacker.
Executing POP3 commands coming from an untrusted source can cause the POP3 server to execute malicious commands on behalf of an attacker.
Executing SMTP commands from an untrusted source can cause the SMTP server to execute malicious commands on behalf of an attacker.
Failure to enable validation when parsing XML gives an attacker the opportunity to supply malicious input.
Failure to enable validation when parsing XML gives an attacker the opportunity to supply malicious input.
The evaluation of unvalidated OGNL expressions can lead to remote code execution.

The Url built using the Struts 2 <s:url /> or <s:a /> tags evaluates the query parameters as OGNL expressions allowing an attacker to modify system variables like Session or execute arbitrary commands on the server.
Allowing unvalidated input to control the URL used in a redirect can aid phishing attacks.
Allowing user input to control paths used in filesystem operations could enable an attacker to access or modify otherwise protected system resources.
Allowing user input to control paths used in filesystem operations could enable an attacker to overwrite files arbitrarily anywhere on the system.
Loading libraries from an untrusted source or in an untrusted environment can cause an application to execute malicious commands on behalf of an attacker.
The InvokerServlet class can allow attackers to invoke any class on the server.

TITULO: Query String Injection: Amazon Web Services
ABSTRACT: Constructing a SimpleDB select statement that contains user input can allow an attacker to view unauthorized records.
Constructing a SQLite query statement that contains user input can allow an attacker to view unauthorized records.
The application allows an attacker to craft a URL that forces a download of arbitrary content that appears to have originated from a trusted domain.
Allowing user input to control resource identifiers could enable an attacker to access or modify otherwise protected system resources.
Constructing a dynamic SQL statement with input coming from an untrusted source could allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning or to execute arbitrary SQL commands.
Using Hibernate to execute a dynamic SQL statement built with input coming from an untrusted source can allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning or to execute arbitrary SQL commands.

Using Java Data Objects (JDO) to execute a dynamic SQL or JDOQL statement built with input coming from an untrusted source can allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning or to execute arbitrary SQL commands.
Constructing a dynamic SQL statement with input coming from an untrusted source could allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning or to execute arbitrary SQL commands.
Constructing a dynamic SQL statement with input coming from an untrusted source could allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning or to execute arbitrary SQL commands.
Constructing a dynamic SQL statement with input coming from an untrusted source could allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning or to execute arbitrary SQL commands.
The application initiates a network connection to a third-party system using user-controlled data to craft the resource URI.
Allowing external control of system settings can disrupt service or cause an application to behave in unexpected ways.
An Action Field was found without a corresponding validation definition.
Multiple Struts2 field validator references with the same name exist. Duplicate validator references are an indication that validation is not up to date.
Multiple Struts2 Validation files exist for this Action. Multiple validation forms are an indication that validation is not up to date.
Multiple Struts2 validator references with the same name exist. Duplicate validator references are an indication that validation is not up to date.
A validator referenced in ActionClass-validation.xml is not declared in validators.xml
Struts2 Actions should utilize the Struts Validation framework to prevent vulnerabilities that result from unchecked input.
Struts2 Validation file found with no corresponding Struts2 Action.
A Struts2 validator is defined for an action field that does not exist.
Multiple validation forms with the same name indicate that validation logic is not up-to-date.
The validator form defines a validate() method that fails to call super.validate().

TITULO: Struts: Form Does Not Extend Validation Class
ABSTRACT: All Struts forms should extend a Validator class.
Every field in a form should be validated in the corresponding validation form.

TITULO: Struts: Plugin Framework Not In Use
ABSTRACT: Use the Struts Validator to prevent vulnerabilities that result from unchecked input.
An unused action form indicates that application logic might not be up-to-date.
An unused validation form indicates that validation logic is not up-to-date.
Every Action Form must have a corresponding validation form.
This action form mapping disables the form's validate() method.
Validation fields that do not appear in forms they are associated with indicate that the validation logic is out of date.
Revealing system data or debugging information helps an adversary learn about the system and form a plan of attack.
Improper use of the Java Native Interface (JNI) can render Java applications vulnerable to security flaws in other languages.
An attacker may be able to create unexpected control flow paths through the application, potentially bypassing security checks.
Using XML parsers configured to not prevent nor limit Document Type Definition (DTD) entity resolution can expose the parser to an XML Entity Expansion injection
Using XML parsers configured to not prevent nor limit external entities resolution can expose the parser to an XML External Entities attack
Writing unvalidated data into an XML document can allow an attacker to change the structure and contents of the XML.
Constructing a dynamic XPath query with user input could allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning.
Constructing a dynamic XQuery expression with user input could allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning.
Processing an unvalidated XSL stylesheet can allow an attacker to change the structure and contents of the resultant XML, include arbitrary files from the file system, or execute arbitrary Java code.
Accessing a SimpleDB database with a user-controlled item name and without proper access control can allow an attacker to view unauthorized records.
Without proper access control, executing a SQLite statement that contains a user-controlled primary key can allow an attacker to view unauthorized records.
Without proper access control, executing an LDAP statement that contains a user-controlled value can allow an attacker to access unauthorized records.
OWASP: A7 Missing Function Level Access Control

ABSTRACT: Without proper access control, executing a SQL statement that contains a user-controlled primary key can allow an attacker to view unauthorized records.
Without proper access control, executing an LDAP statement that contains a user-controlled value can allow an attacker to access unauthorized directory entries.
Invoking this function on untrusted code can allow attackers access to restricted packages and provides them with the ability to execute arbitrary code.
OWASP: A7 Missing Function Level Access Control

ABSTRACT: Weak security constraints do not provide adequate protection for security-critical resources.
OWASP: A7 Missing Function Level Access Control

ABSTRACT: Allowing users jump between HTTP and HTTPS leaves the application vulnerable to session hijacking.
Using the Run-As authentication replacement feature in Acegi can lead to a privilege escalation vulnerability.
OWASP: A2 Broken Authentication and Session Management

TITULO: Android Bad Practices: Just Provider writePermission Defined
ABSTRACT: The program declares a content provider with only the writePermission defined.

TITULO: Android Bad Practices: Missing Broadcaster Permission
ABSTRACT: The program registers a receiver without specifying the broadcaster permission.

TITULO: Android Bad Practices: Missing Component Permission
ABSTRACT: The program does not explicitly assign an access permission to this public component.

TITULO: Android Bad Practices: Missing Receiver Permission
ABSTRACT: The program sends a broadcast without specifying the receiver permission.

TITULO: Android Bad Practices: Missing exported Flag or Component Permission
ABSTRACT: The program does not explicitly assign an access permission to a component.

TITULO: Android Bad Practices: Mixed Component Functionality
ABSTRACT: This receiver component is registered to receive messages from the system and also other components.

TITULO: Android Bad Practices: Provider Permission Defined
ABSTRACT: The program declares a content provider with the combined read and write access permission.
The program sends a sticky broadcast.

TITULO: Android Bad Practices: System Permission Defined
ABSTRACT: The program defines a new permission on the android.permission namespace.

TITULO: Android Bad Practices: Unnecessary Component Exposure
ABSTRACT: This receiver component is  unnecessarily accessible to third-party components increasing the risk of malicious information injection.
The program uses private and/or device specific information to generate a universally unique identifier.
The program declares a permission with the normal protection level.
The configuration should ensure SSL is required for access to sensitive information.
The configuration should ensure SSL is required for access to sensitive information.

TITULO: Cookie Security: Cookie not Sent Over SSL
ABSTRACT: A cookie is created without the secure flag set to true.
A cookie with an overly broad domain opens an application to attacks through other applications.
A cookie with an overly broad path can be accessed through other applications on the same domain.
Storing sensitive data in a persistent cookie can lead to a breach of confidentiality or account compromise.
Security constraints that specify HTTP verbs often allow more access than intended.
Standard pseudorandom number generators cannot withstand cryptographic attacks.
Functions that generate random or pseudorandom values, which are passed a seed, should not be called with a constant argument.
Functions that generate random or pseudorandom values, which are passed a seed, should not be called with a tainted integer argument.
The application implements a custom SSL interface.

TITULO: Insecure SSL: Android Hostname Verification Disabled
ABSTRACT: Hostname verification is disabled when making SSL connections.
The method fails to make SSL verification checks.

TITULO: Insecure SSL: Server Identity Verification Disabled
ABSTRACT: Server identity verification is disabled when making SSL connections.
The call uses an unencrypted protocol instead of an encrypted protocol to communicate with the server.
Establishing an unencrypted connection to a mail server allows an attacker to carry out a man-in-the-middle attack and read all the mail transmissions.
The application configuration should ensure that SSL is used for all access controlled pages.
Empty encryption keys may compromise system security in a way that cannot be easily remedied.
Empty HMAC keys could compromise system security in a way that cannot be easily remedied.
Hardcoded encryption keys may compromise system security in a way that cannot be easily remedied.
Hardcoded HMAC keys could compromise system security in a way that cannot be easily remedied.
Null encryption keys may compromise system security in a way that cannot be easily remedied.
A cloneable class that performs this check in its constructor needs to perform the same check in its clone() method.
A serializable class that performs a SecurityManager check in its constructor needs to perform the same check in its readObject() and readObjectNoData methods.
Mishandling private information, such as customer passwords or social security numbers, can compromise user privacy and is often illegal.
Storing a password in plaintext can result in a system compromise.
Empty passwords may compromise system security in a way that cannot be easily remedied.
Hardcoded passwords may compromise system security in a way that cannot be easily remedied.
Null passwords can compromise security.
Storing passwords or password details in plaintext anywhere in the system or system code may compromise system security in a way that cannot be easily remedied.
Sending a password as part of an HTTP redirect will cause the password to be displayed, logged, or stored in a cache.
Obscuring a password with a trivial encoding does not protect the password.
Mishandling private information, such as customer passwords or social security numbers, can compromise user privacy and is often illegal.
Mishandling private information, such as customer passwords or social security numbers, can compromise user privacy and is often illegal.
Storing sensitive data in a String object makes it impossible to reliably purge the data from memory.
A viewed password endangers system security.

TITULO: Privilege Management: Amazon Web Services Unchecked Permissions
ABSTRACT: Unchecked arguments to methods that control permissions or access control lists can allow attackers to access sensitive data.
The program requests permission to write data to Android's external storage.
The program requests permission to disable the handset.
The program requests permission to access the device's GPS location.
The program asks to perform SMS operations.
The program requests permission to make a network connection.
The program requests permission to make and receive telephone calls.
The program attempts to perform an operation without requesting the required permission.

TITULO: Privilege Management: Missing Content Provider Permission
ABSTRACT: The program attempts to perform an operation without requesting the required permission.
The program attempts to perform an operation without requesting the required permission.

TITULO: Privilege Management: Overly Broad Access Specifier
ABSTRACT: Privileged code in public methods can be called from anywhere in the JVM.
Some functions may enable a programmer to be able to override the permissions specified by a user on an Android device at certain times.
The application fails to adhere to the principle of least privilege, which greatly amplifies the risk posed by other vulnerabilities.
The program transits information over insecure HTTP connections.
Weak cryptographic hashes cannot guarantee data integrity and should not be used in security-critical contexts.

TITULO: Weak Cryptographic Hash: Hardcoded PBE Salt
ABSTRACT: A hardcoded salt may compromise system security in a way that cannot be easily remedied.
A hardcoded salt may compromise system security in a way that cannot be easily remedied.

TITULO: Weak Cryptographic Hash: Insecure PBE Iteration Count
ABSTRACT: The iteration count used by a password-based key derivation function is too low.

TITULO: Weak Cryptographic Hash: Missing Required Step
ABSTRACT: The code misses invoking a required step during the process of generating a cryptographic hash.
Using a user-controlled algorithm within a cryptographic hash may enable the attacker to specify a weak cryptographic hash algorithm, compromising data integrity and security of the application.

TITULO: Weak Cryptographic Hash: User-Controlled PBE Salt
ABSTRACT: Potentially tainted user inputs should not be passed as the salt parameter to a Password-Based Key Derivation Function (PBKDF).
Methods that generate cryptographic hashes, which are passed a salt, should not be called with a tainted salt argument.

TITULO: Weak Cryptographic Signature: Missing Required Step
ABSTRACT: The code misses invoking a required step during the process of generating a cryptographic signature.
The identified call uses a weak encryption algorithm that cannot guarantee the confidentiality of sensitive data.

TITULO: Weak Encryption: Byte Array to String Conversion
ABSTRACT: Converting an encryption key to a String can lead to a significant loss of entropy.
Public key RSA encryption is performed without using OAEP padding, thereby making the encryption weak.
Initialization vectors should be created using a cryptographic pseudorandom number generator.

TITULO: Weak Encryption: Insecure Mode of Operation
ABSTRACT: Cryptographic encryption algorithms should not be used with an insecure mode of operation.
An otherwise strong encryption algorithm is vulnerable to brute-force attack when a small key size is used.
The code misses invoking a required step during a symmetric key generation, encryption, or decryption process.
Encryption functions that take a key size parameter should not be passed a tainted key size value.
Non-final methods that perform security checks can be overridden in ways that bypass security checks.
OWASP: A7 Missing Function Level Access Control

TITULO: Code Correctness: Call to sleep() in Lock
ABSTRACT: Calling sleep() while holding a lock can cause a loss of performance and might cause a deadlock.
Double-checked locking is an incorrect idiom that does not achieve the intended effect.

TITULO: J2EE Bad Practices: Insufficient Session Expiration
ABSTRACT: The method sets up a session that never expires.
OWASP: A2 Broken Authentication and Session Management

ABSTRACT: A web application should not attempt to shut down its container.

TITULO: J2EE Bad Practices: Non-Serializable Object Stored in Session
ABSTRACT: Storing a non-serializable object as an HttpSession attribute can damage application reliability.
OWASP: A2 Broken Authentication and Session Management

ABSTRACT: Thread management in a web application is forbidden in some circumstances and is always highly error prone.
The methods parse() and format() in java.text.Format contain a design flaw that can cause one user to see another user's data.
Servlet member fields might allow one user to see another user's data.
Database connections stored in static fields will be shared between threads.
Authenticating a user without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.
OWASP: A2 Broken Authentication and Session Management
